St. Dominic as founder of the Dominican order
confirmation of the Dominican order by pope Innocent III (or Honorius III)
early life of St. Dominic
the vision of St. Dominic's mother: she dreams she gives birth to a black and white dog with a flaming torch in its mouth
at St. Dominic's baptism, his godmother sees a star descend on his brow

visions of St. Dominic
the Virgin Mary (or the infant Christ in her lap) hands over a rosary to St. Dominic, who kneels before her; usually St. Catharine of Siena is also present
St. Dominic receives the commission to preach: St. Peter and St. Paul appear to him in a vision and give him a staff and a book (the gospels)

the Virgin Mary, interceding for mankind, presents St. Dominic and usually also St. Francis of Assisi to Christ; Christ brandishes three spears or arrows to destroy the sins of Pride, Avarice and Lust

St. Dominic scourging himself

miraculous activities and events ~ St. Dominic
the dream of pope Innocent III: he sees the Lateran Church toppling, and St. Dominic holding it up with his hands
St. Dominic, surrounded by the Albigense heretics, throws his book into the fire but it leaps out intact, while the heretical books are consumed by the fire
St. Dominic resurrects young Napoleon Orsini, who was killed by a fall from his horse
St. Dominic rescues pilgrims who were drowning in the river Garonne
at supper St. Dominic and some friars are served with bread by two angels

St. George is stretched on a wheel with knives: the wheel is destroyed by angels
St. George is put in a cauldron of boiling oil
St. George is hung upside down above a fire
St. George is sawn in two

St. George is ripped up by iron nails
St. George drinks from a poisoned cup
St. George is beheaded

St. Barbara's breasts are cut off

ox (possibly with book) ~ symbol of St. Luke
lion (possibly with book) ~ symbol of St. Mark
angel (possibly with book) ~ symbol of St. Matthew
anthropomorphic symbols of the evangelists
human figure with eagle's head ~ symbol of St. John
human figure with ox' head ~ symbol of St. Luke
human figure with lion's head ~ symbol of St. Mark
human figure ~ symbol of St. Matthew
the Tetramorph: human figure with four or six wings
Tetramorph: human figure with four different heads (human head, ox, eagle, lion)
Tetramorph: fabulous animal with four different heads and four different legs

the four evangelists ~ Doctors of the Church
the four evangelists ~ the four main prophets

Last Judgement

comprehensive representation of Last Judgement: Christ (with sword and lily), often surrounded by elders and sometimes accompanied by Mary and John the Baptist, appears in the sky with trumpeting angels (and sometimes angels holding the instruments of the Passion); after the resurrection of the dead the blessed are led to heaven by angels, and the damned are dragged into hell by devils

when Moses is old enough, his mother brings him to Pharaoh's daughter, who adopts him
Moses is educated in the king's palace
Moses and Pharaoh's crown: Pharaoh playfully places his crown on the head of the infant Moses, who throws it to the ground and tramples on it; or Moses breaks the crown while playing
Moses' trial by fire: when given the choice between two plates, one containing burning coals, the other a ruby ring (or cherries), Moses chooses the burning coals and puts them in his mouth
the infant Moses among the philosophers
Moses and his people; the flight to Midian (Exodus 2:11-25)
Moses sees how the Israelites are forced to do hard labour
Moses beholding one of his countrymen being beaten by an Egyptian taskmaster
Moses kills the Egyptian taskmaster
Moses buries the body of the Egyptian taskmaster in the sand
Moses, when rebuking two Israelites who were quarrelling, is upbraided for the murder of the Egyptian
Pharaoh is informed of the murder of the Egyptian
Moses flees to Midian
Moses at a well meets the seven daughters of Jethro, the priest of Midian
Moses drives away the shepherds who wanted to prevent Jethro's daughters from watering their father's flock
Moses waters the sheep of Jethro's daughters
the seven daughters of Jethro return home
Moses is received in Jethro's house
Moses' marriage with Zipporah
birth of Gershom, son of Moses
Pharaoh's death
God looking upon the Israelites
the calling of Moses (Exodus 3-4)
while tending Jethro's flock Moses comes to Horeb
a burning bush attracts Moses' attention
the burning bush ~ calling of Moses
Moses taking off his sandals
Moses, kneeling before the bush and hiding his face, listens to God
the miracles ~ the calling of Moses
miracle of the rod changed into a serpent ; Moses may be shown fleeing from the serpent
miracle of the leprous hand ~ Moses and the burning bush
miracle of the water changed to blood ~ burning bush
Moses is given a rod
Moses and Jethro parting ~ the calling of Moses
Moses departs for Egypt: he carries his rod and is accompanied by his wife and sons upon an ass
at an inn, God (or the angel of God) tries to kill Moses
Zipporah appeases God by circumcising one of her sons
God appears to Aaron
Aaron meets Moses and kisses him
Moses and Aaron gather all the Israelite leaders
Aaron speaking to the Israelites
Moses performing the miracles before the people
Moses communicating with God (in general)
Moses and Aaron confront Pharaoh (Exodus 5-7:13)
Pharaoh commands the taskmasters to stop supplying the people with straw for making bricks
the Israelites complain to Moses and Aaron (~ Pharaoh)
Moses instructing the Israelites
Moses and Aaron before Pharaoh; Aaron performs the miracle of the rod changing into a snake
all the magicians summoned by the king turn their rods into snakes, but Aaron's rod swallows them
the ten plagues (Exodus 7:14 - 11:10, 12:21-30)
recurrent scenes ~ the ten plagues
Moses (and Aaron) before Pharaoh enthroned (recurrent scene ~ the ten plagues)
Moses (and Aaron) causing a plague to cease (recurrent scene ~ the ten plagues)
servants complaining to Pharaoh (recurrent scene ~ the ten plagues)
the ten plagues (part I)
the plague of water turned into blood: as Pharaoh goes down to the Nile, Aaron strikes the surface of the river with his rod; the water turns into blood and all the fishes die
the plague of frogs: Aaron stretches out his hand over the water of Egypt; frogs come out and cover the land
frogs invading pharaoh's palace (Exodus 7:26-29 or 8:1-4)
the plague of lice: Aaron strikes the ground with his rod and the dust turns into lice
the plague of flies which fill the houses of the Egyptians
the plague of murrain in cattle: all the animals of the Egyptians die
the plague of boils: Moses throws a handful of ashes into the air in front of Pharaoh and it produces boils on the people and the animals
the plague of hail: Moses raises his rod towards the sky, and hail and fire fall to the ground
the plague of locusts: as Moses raises his hands the locusts come and eat everything that has survived the hail
the plague of darkness: Moses raises his hands towards the sky and there is total darkness for three days
the ten plagues (part II)
preliminaries to the tenth plague
Moses predicting the death of the first-born
Moses proclaims the Passover
celebration of the first Passover
with lamb's blood the Israelites make marks (usually tau-crosses) on the doorposts of their houses
the Israelites eat the Passover lamb standing about a table with their loins girt, their shoes on their feet and with staves in their hands, ready to depart
the plague of the first-born: the destroying angel passes through the land and kills every Egyptian first-born of man and animal
Pharaoh mourning his dead son ~ the tenth plague
the Israelites leave Egypt; first movement from Rameses to Succoth (Exodus 12:31 - 13:16)
during the night Pharaoh sends for Moses and Aaron and begs them to depart
the Egyptians urging the Israelites to leave the country
the Israelites prepare to leave: the people fill their troughs with unleavened dough, wrap them in clothing and carry them on their shoulders
the Egyptians handing over their jewellery and clothing to the Israelites
the Israelites bake unleavened bread from the dough
the dedication of the first-born
Exodus (part II): journey of Israel to Mount Sinai
journey of the Israelites from Succoth to the Red Sea (Exodus 13:17-20)
Moses takes the bones of Joseph with him
the pillar of cloud and the pillar of fire ~ Exodus
during the day a pillar of cloud (and/or the angel of God) shows the people the way
by night a pillar of fire gives the Israelites light (Exodus 14)
passage through the Red Sea
Pharaoh is told of the flight of the Israelites
Pharaoh and his army set off in pursuit of the Israelites
the people of Israel murmur against Moses
Moses lifts up his rod and the water divides (Red Sea); the angel of God and the pillar of cloud move to the rear
the people pass over on dry land (Egyptians not or barely visible); the angel of God and the pillar of cloud may be shown at the rear
the Egyptians pursuing the Israelites into the sea
with his people safe on the shore, Moses raises his hands and causes the water to return; Pharaoh's army perishes in the water (Red Sea)
Pharaoh and his army engulfed in the Red Sea (Israelites not or barely visible)
after crossing the Red Sea the Israelites rejoice and praise God (Exodus 15:1-21)
song of Moses ~ Exodus
Miriam takes up a tambourine and dances; all the women follow her
Miriam's song of praise ~ Exodus
the Israelites at Marah and Elim (Exodus 15:22-27)
miracle of the sweetening of the water of Marah
in the wilderness the people murmur against Moses about the bitter water
Moses throws a piece of wood into the water of Marah, which then becomes sweet
the Israelites listen to God
the Israelites come to the oasis of Elim, where they find twelve springs and seventy palmtrees
the twelve springs of Elim (one for each tribe)
miracle of the manna and the quails (Exodus 16)
in the desert of Sin Israel complains to Moses
Moses and Aaron promise food to the people
the glory of God appears
in the evening a large flock of quails flies into the Israelite camp
in the morning manna falls to the earth ~ Exodus
the gathering of manna (in baskets and pots)
Aaron fills a jar with manna to be kept in the tabernacle
the jar with the 'omer' of manna
Moses striking water from the rock (Exodus 17:1-7; Numbers 20:2-13)
the Israelites come to Rephidim (or Meribah) and complain because there is no drinking-water
when Moses and Aaron pray in front of the tabernacle, God appears to them
Moses strikes the rock twice in front of the assembled people and water gushes out; the people quench their thirst
God reprimanding Moses
the Amalekites come to war against the Israelites (Exodus 17:8-16)
Moses instructing Joshua
Moses goes to the top of a hill with Aaron and Hur and raises his arms to make the Israelites victorious
Moses sitting on a rock, arms held up by Aaron and Hur; the Amalekites are defeated
Moses builds an altar
Jethro's visit to Moses: with Zipporah and her two sons he comes to the desert where Moses is encamped (Exodus 18)
Jethro and Moses meeting
Jethro in Moses' tent
Jethro offers a sacrifice to God and eats bread with Moses, Aaron and all the leaders of Israel
Jethro, when seeing Moses busy the whole day settling disputes among the people, advises him to appoint some judges
Moses choosing judges
Moses and Jethro parting ~ Jethro's visit to Moses in the desert
Exodus (part III): conclusion of the Sinaitic law and its renewal
recurrent themes ~ Mount Sinai
Moses (alone) ascending Mount Sinai
Moses communicating with God on Mount Sinai (the mountain may be covered by a thick cloud)
Moses coming down from Mount Sinai
Moses addressing the elders
Moses addressing the Israelites
arrival of the Israelites at Mount Sinai (Exodus 19, 20:18-21)
the Israelites come to Mount Sinai and set up camp at the foot of the mountain
the people promise obedience towards God
the people get ready for the coming legislation: they wash their clothes and set bounds round the mountain
Mount Sinai is covered by a thick cloud, thunder and lightning
Moses leads the people to the foot of the mountain and is called by God
God's covenant with Moses is confirmed with a sacrifice (Exodus 24:1-8)
Moses writing down the law
Moses builds an altar and sets up twelve stones
the young men bring offerings; Moses takes half the blood of the animals and sprinkles it on the altar
Moses reading the book of the covenant to the people
Moses takes the bowls with the other half of the sacrificial blood and sprinkles it on the people
Moses on Mount Sinai with the tables of the law (Exodus 24:9-18, 31:18)
Moses ascends the mountain with Aaron, Nadab, Abihu and seventy leaders
Moses and his companions see God on Mount Sinai
Moses tells the elders to stay behind and ascends Mount Sinai further with Joshua
Moses receives the tables of the law from God
God writing the commandments on the two stone tablets
Moses writing the commandments on the two stone tablets
the adoration of the golden calf ~ Aaron (Exodus 32:1-19)
the people ask Aaron to make some idols
the people bring their golden ear-rings to Aaron
Aaron makes a golden calf and has it placed on a pedestal or altar

Aaron builds an altar and offers a sacrifice to the golden calf
the people dance around the golden calf ~ Exodus
the people feasting ~ adoration of the golden calf
Hur dies choked when spit upon by the Israelites for refusing to adore the golden calf
Moses (and Joshua) come(s) down with the stone tablets
on seeing the idolaters Moses breaks the tables of the law
the punishment ~ adoration of the golden calf (Exodus 32:20-35, 33)
Moses melts the calf, grinds the gold into fine powder, mixes it with water and makes the people drink it
Moses calls Aaron to account
Moses, standing at the gate of the camp, causes the Levites to kill all the idolaters
God sends a plague on the people
God relents and sends an angel who will guide the people to Canaan
the people mourn and take off their jewellery ~ punishment of the idolators
when Moses abides in the tabernacle, the pillar of cloud comes down and stays at the door; the people gather at the entrance of their tents and bow down in reverence
Moses, standing on a cliff, sees God from behind
the new tables of the law (Exodus 34)
Moses cuts two stone tablets
Moses carries the two stone tablets up Mount Sinai
God renews the covenant with Moses and writes the law on the tablets
Moses comes down with the new tablets and is awaited by Aaron and the assembled people, who notice that 'his face is shining' (Moses' face is depicted with rays of light or with horns)
Moses covers his face with a veil
preparation and setting up of the Tabernacle and its accessories ~ Exodus (Exodus 35-40)
the people bring their offerings for the Tabernacle: all kinds of fine objects, jewellery, linen, etc.
Moses appoints Bezaleel, Aholiab and other craftsmen
the making of the Tabernacle and its accessories ~ Exodus
the completion of the Tabernacle and its accessories; Moses examines everything and blesses the craftsmen
the Tabernacle is set up and Moses puts the ark with the tables in it
dedication of the Tabernacle (Exodus 40:16-33; Leviticus 8:10-11)
a cloud covers the Tabernacle, which is then filled with glory (when the cloud rises from the Tabernacle the Israelites break camp) (Exodus 40:34-38; Numbers 9:15-23)
by night, fire stays on the Tabernacle
the book Leviticus
Aaron and his four sons are ordained by Moses (Leviticus 8)
Aaron offers sacrifices (Leviticus 9)
when Moses and Aaron bless the people, the glory of God appears to the congregation
God sends fire which consumes the offerings on the altar
the sin of Nadab and Abihu (Leviticus 10:1-7)
two sons of Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, offer incense in their censers to God, who punishes them for this by sending a fire that kills them
Moses explaining the incident to Aaron
the bodies of Nadab and Abihu are carried off from the camp
Moses advises Aaron and his remaining sons, Eleazar and Ithamar, not to mourn with the people
the blasphemer's punishment (Leviticus 24:10-23)
for having cursed God during a quarrel, the son of Shelomith is brought before Moses
the son of Shelomith is stoned to death by the Israelites
God promises prosperity to those who keep his commandments, and destruction to those who break them (Leviticus 26)
Numbers: the wandering in the wilderness, the Israelites leave Mount Sinai and reach Canaan
Numbers (part I): from Mount Sinai to Kadesh
preparations to leave Mount Sinai (Numbers 1-9:14)
the first numbering of the people ~ book of Numbers
Moses, when communicating with God in the Tabernacle, is ordered to number the people
Moses, Aaron and the leaders of the twelve tribes take the census
the tribes are arranged in their proper order ~ the book of Numbers
the Levites are appointed to serve the priests
census of the Levites
duties of the Levite clans
duties of the Levite clans (with NAME of clan)
the Levites take the place of the first-born sons
purification and dedication of the Levites
the unclean are expelled from the camp ~ the book of Numbers
offerings of the leaders of the tribes at the dedication of the Tabernacle
Aaron lights the Tabernacle lamps
celebration of the second Passover
the departure from Mount Sinai (Numbers 10)
signals for breaking camp ~ book of Numbers
two silver trumpets are made and are used to call the people together ~ the book of Numbers
the Israelites break camp and start on their journey ~ the book of Numbers
Moses entreats Hobab, Jethro's son, to come with them
the people are discontent (Numbers 11)
at Taberah the people are punished by fire which consumes one end of the camp
the fire ceases when Moses prays
Moses chooses seventy elders to assist him and places them round the Tabernacle; the spirit of God descends upon them
Eldad and Medad prophesying
a multitude of quail falls and covers the camp
when the people eat the quails a plague breaks out
the Israelites move to Hazeroth
sedition of Miriam and Aaron (Numbers 12)
Aaron and Miriam complaining of Moses
God comes down in the pillar of cloud at the door of the Tabernacle and rebukes Aaron and Miriam
Miriam is punished with leprosy; Moses prays to God, who promises to heal Miriam after seven days
Miriam is shut out of the camp for seven days
healed Miriam returns to the camp
the Israelites leave Hazeroth for the desert of Pharan
reconnaissance of Canaan (Numbers 13-14)
Moses sends out twelve spies to explore the land of Canaan
the spies take away some of the fruits of Canaan and return, usually carrying a large bunch of grapes on a pole
the grapes of Canaan
the spies, except for Caleb and Joshua, bring startling reports which upset the people ~ reconnaissance of Canaan
Caleb urges the people to conquer Canaan
the people complain ~ reconnaissance of Canaan
Moses and Aaron bow to the ground before the assembly, while Joshua and Caleb rend their clothes
the people threaten to stone Moses, Aaron, Joshua and Caleb, but suddenly the glory of God appears over the Tabernacle (the four men may be seen protected by a cloud)

when Moses reports God's punishment to the people they mourn bitterly ~ reconnaissance of Canaan

punishment of the sabbath-breaker (Numbers 15:32-36)
a man found gathering wood on the sabbath is brought before Moses and Aaron
the sabbath-breaker is stoned to death ~ the book of Numbers
rebellion of Korah (Core), Dathan and Abiram, and their punishment (Numbers 16)

Moses reproving Korah
Moses taunted by Dathan and Abiram, who refuse to appear before him

Moses goes to the dwellings of Dathan and Abiram and warns the people to move away from their tents

the priest Eleazar gathers the censers from the remains of the men who have been burnt

the people complain about the death of the rebels (Korah, Dathan and Abiram)

Aaron, with his censer running into the middle of the assembled people, stops the plague, and stands between the living and the dead

Aaron's rod has sprouted, flowered and produced ripe almonds
Moses shows the flowering rod of Aaron to the community

events at Kadesh (Numbers 20:1, 20:14-21)
death and burial of Miriam
the king of Edom refuses to let Israel pass
Moses sends messengers to the king of Edom
the Edomites march out with an army; the Israelites are compelled to take another route
death of Aaron (Numbers 20:22-29)
Moses ascends Mount Hor with Aaron and Eleazar
Moses removes Aaron's priestly robes and puts them on Eleazar
Aaron's burial
the people mourn for Aaron
victory over the Canaanites led by King Arad (Numbers 21:1-3)
the brazen serpent (Numbers 21:4-9)
when the people complain again about the food, God sends poisonous snakes; many die of snake-bites ~ book of Numbers
Moses, petitioned by the Israelites, entreats God to take the snakes away
a serpent of brass is made and is set on a pole
anyone who is bitten by a snake is cured by looking at the brazen serpent; the serpent (or dragon) is usually depicted on a tau-shaped cross or on a pillar
the Israelites on their way to the valley of the Moabites (Numbers 21:10-20)
a well is dug at Beer
victory of the Israelites over King Sihon and King Og (Numbers 21:21-35; Joshua 12:1-6)
messengers of the Israelites are sent to the Amorite King Sihon
battle of the Israelites against the Amorites during their journey through the desert

Moses sends spies to the city of Jaazer
battle of the Israelites against King Og
Numbers (part III): events in Moab
the story of Balaam (Numbers 22-24)
the Moabite King Balak, alarmed by the arrival of the Israelites, sends messengers to Balaam to pronounce a curse on them
Balaam receives the messengers of the Moabite King Balak
God appears to Balaam in a dream
Balaam sends the messengers of King Balak away
the messengers report to King Balak of their visit to the prophet Balaam
new messengers are sent to Balaam
God appears to the prophet Balaam for the second time
Balaam saddles his donkey and departs with the Moabite messengers
an angel holding a sword bars the way and causes Balaam's ass to turn aside; the angel is invisible to Balaam
Balaam strikes his ass, whereupon the ass lies down and starts to speak
Balaam's eyes open; he throws himself at the feet of the angel
Balaam resumes his journey after the encounter with the angel
Balaam and King Balak meet and together they make a sacrifice
Balaam is taken up to the high places of Baal and sees the Israelite camp
Balaam commands seven altars, seven bulls and seven rams to be prepared for a sacrifice in the presence of King Balak
Balaam sacrificing the seven bulls and the seven rams in the presence of King Balak
Balaam communicating with God after his sacrifice of seven bulls and seven rams
Balaam prophesying and blessing the Israelites in the presence of King Balak and his chieftains
Balaam is brought by King Balak to Mount Pisgah to make a second sacrifice of bulls and rams
Balaam is brought by King Balak to Mount Peor to make a third sacrifice of bulls and rams and sees the Israelites abiding in their tents
Balaam the prophet is rebuked by King Balak
Balaam's final prophecies ~ the Israelites: 'star of Jacob'
Balaam parting from Balak
the Israelites' stay at Shittim during their journey through the desert (Numbers 25)
the Israelites and the Moabite women
the Israelites have intercourse with the Moabite women
the Moabite women lead the Israelites into the worship of Baal-Peor
the Israelites who had intercourse with the Moabite women are punished
Zimri takes a Midianite woman, Cozbi, into his tent, while the people are lamenting at the entrance of the Tabernacle on account of an epidemic
Phinehas, Eleazar's son, follows Zimri and Cozbi and drives his spear through both of them
the second numbering of the Israelites (Numbers 26)
Moses petitioned by the five daughters of Zelophehad (Numbers 27:1-11)
Joshua is chosen as successor to Moses, who places his hands on Joshua's head in front of Eleazar the high priest and the assembled congregation (Numbers 27:18-23)
war of the Israelites against the Midianites (Numbers 31)
Moses commanding the attack on the Midianites
all the Midianite men, including their five kings and Balaam, are killed; the women, children and animals are captured, and the cities are burnt
the Israelite army returns with the spoils after the battle against the Midianites
Moses orders the death of the mature Midianite women and their male children after the victory of the Israelites over the Midianites
the Israelites washing their clothes after the battle against the Midianites
division of the spoils after the battle of the Israelites against the Midianites
the officer's oblation after the battle of the Israelites against the Midianites; Moses and Eleazar take the gifts to the Tabernacle
before crossing the Jordan (Numbers 32-36)
the country east of the Jordan is given to the tribes of Reuben, Gad and half of the tribe of Manasseh
petition of the Reubenites and Gadites; they ask permission to stay in the country east of the Jordan; Moses becomes furious at this demand
the Gadites building cities
the Reubenites building cities
battle for Gilead
Moses petitioned by the heads of the Gilead family, who want the daughters of Zelophehad not to marry outside their own tribe
the daughters of Zelophehad marry their cousins
Deuteronomy: the crowning events of the wanderings; Moses prepares for his death
Moses teaching (in general)
Joshua's vocation (Deuteronomy 31:7-8, 31:14-15)
Joshua encouraged by Moses in the presence of the assembled people
Moses brings Joshua to the Tabernacle; the pillar of cloud stays at the door of the tent
Moses writes down the legislation during the last days before his death (Deuteronomy 31 passim)

Moses gathers the people and recites his canticle just before his death (Deuteronomy 31 passim, 32)
Moses blesses the twelve tribes of Israel just before his death (Deuteronomy 33)
Moses' death (Deuteronomy 34)
Moses from Mount Nebo views the promised land
God buries Moses on Mount Nebo
the Israelites mourn Moses for thirty days
the contest of St. Michael and Satan for the body of Moses on Mount Nebo (Jude 9)
the book of Joshua (Josue)
Joshua communicating with God (in general)
the conquest of Canaan by the Israelites under Joshua's leadership (part I)
Joshua preparing to enter the promised land (Joshua 1-2)
Joshua instructs the officers, and is accepted as the new leader of the Israelites
Joshua sends two spies to explore Jericho
story of Rahab and the spies
the two spies sent by Joshua find lodging at the house of Rahab, a harlot
the king of Jericho is told that two Israelites have come, and he sends a searching-party to find them
Rahab hides the two spies on her roof under stalks of flax
Rahab, questioned by the king's men about the Israelite spies, sends them on a false track
Rahab exacts from the spies the promise that she and her family will be spared when the city falls
Rahab, whose house was built in the city wall, lets the spies down from the window by means of a red rope
the Israelite spies hide in the hills for three days while the soldiers of the king of Jericho search for them all over the countryside
the spies return to the Israelite camp and report to Joshua
the Israelites come to the Jordan (Joshua 3-4)
the Israelites move their camp to the Jordan, waiting to cross it
the officers instruct the Israelites how to cross the river Jordan
Joshua instructs the priests ~ crossing the Jordan
the Israelites leave their camp to cross the Jordan; the priests, carrying the ark, lead the march
the crossing of the Jordan by the Israelites
as soon as the priests step into the river the water of the Jordan stops flowing
while the priests with the ark stay in the middle of the Jordan and the waters are miraculously dammed, the Israelites cross the river
twelve men take twelve stones from the middle of the river ~ crossing of the Jordan by the Israelites
Joshua sets up twelve stones in the midst of the river to commemorate the miraculous crossing of the Jordan
Joshua is magnified in the sight of the people after the crossing of the river Jordan by the Israelites
when the priests leave the river Jordan at Joshua's command, it begins to flow again
camp at Gilgal after the crossing of the river Jordan (Joshua 4:19 - 5:15)
at Gilgal Joshua erects another monument with the twelve stones taken from the Jordan
Israelites born during the wandering are circumcised after the crossing of the river Jordan
the Passover is celebrated for the first time in the promised land
Joshua encounters an angel holding a sword (at first not recognizing the angel, Joshua may be shown drawing his sword)
Joshua throws himself at the feet of the angel with the sword
Joshua is told by the angel with the sword to take off his sandals
the fall of Jericho (Joshua 6)
Jericho shuts itself up within its walls and prepares to withstand the siege

the Israelites march around Jericho: in the procession the main body of the soldiers comes first, next are seven priests who blow on trumpets, followed by the priests carrying the ark and a rear guard
on the seventh day, at a signal from Joshua, the people start to shout and the walls of Jericho crumble
the Israelites assault the city of Jericho after the walls have come down
Jericho is sacked and burned by the Israelites; the inhabitants are killed
Rahab and her family are spared and taken into the Israelite camp ~ fall of Jericho
the spoils are put into the Lord's treasury ~ the fall of Jericho
Joshua pronounces a curse against anyone who will try to rebuild the city of Jericho
Achan's sin (aftermath of the fall of Jericho) (Joshua 7)
Joshua sends spies to Ai, who report that the city is not large
only three thousand men go up against Ai; they are driven back and some of them are slain
Joshua, prostrate before the Tabernacle, mourns and tears his clothes after the first unsuccessful attack on the city of Ai
Joshua investigates the tribes after the unsuccessful attack on the city of Ai: the tribe of Judah is selected and finally Achan is picked out
Achan confesses to have taken from the spoils a garment and some silver and gold
the goods, stolen from the spoils of Jericho, are found buried in Achan's tent and brought to Joshua
Achan, his family and possessions (including the stolen spoils) are taken to the valley of Achor to be stoned
Achan and his family are stoned and burned (aftermath of the fall of Jericho)
a huge pile of stones is put over Achan and his family, stoned to death because Achan had stolen from the spoils of Jericho
the city of Ai taken by stratagem (Joshua 8:1-29)
Joshua commands some of his soldiers to go into hiding west of the city of Ai
Joshua and the rest of the army set up camp on the north side of the city of Ai
when the king of Ai comes out to fight the Israelites, they retreat and pretend to flee from the enemy
as Joshua points his spear at Ai, the men who were lying in ambush storm the city, capture it and set it on fire; Joshua and his men turn round and kill the men of Ai
the king of Ai is brought to Joshua and hanged
the body of the king of Ai is removed from the tree on which he had been hanged, thrown down before the city-gate and covered with a huge pile of stones
the reading of the law (Joshua 8:30-35)
Joshua sets up an altar on Mount Ebal
the Israelites offer burnt sacrifices on Mount Ebal
Joshua writes on the stones a copy of the law and reads it aloud to the whole congregation, women and children included
the ruse of the Gibeonites (Joshua 9)
the people of Gibeon, fearing Joshua and his men, decide to deceive them: they load their donkeys with worn-out sacks, they put on ragged clothes and old sandals and take decaying food
the people of Gibeon, dressed up in rags, and pretending to have come from a distant land ask Joshua to make a treaty with them

the trick of the Gibeonites is found out; Joshua decrees that thenceforth they must be the servants of the Israelites, they must cut wood and carry water
Joshua and the five kings of South Canaan (Joshua 10:1-27)
the five Amorite kings (viz. from Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish and Eglon) join forces to attack Gibeon
the city of Gibeon being besieged, the inhabitants ask Joshua for help
by night Joshua and his army come to the rescue of Gibeon
Joshua and his army make a surprise attack on the Amorites who are besieging the city of Gibeon

Eliezer warns king Jehoshaphat that the project displeased God
the fleet is shipwrecked ~ Jehoshaphat and Ahaziah
story of Jehoram (Joram), son of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah (2 Kings 8:16-24; 2 Chronicles 21)
Jehoram becomes king of Judah
Jehoram has all his brothers slain
Jehoram marries Athalia, daughter of Ahab and Jezebel of Israel, and allows the Judaean people to worship idols
Edom revolts against Judah
Jehoram and his officers set out and invade Edom
Jehoram and his officers are surrounded by the Edomite army but during the night they manage to break out and escape
the end of Jehoram's reign
Elijah sends a letter to Jehoram predicting his punishment
some Philistines and Arabs invade Judah, loot the royal palace and carry off all Jehoram's wives and sons except Ahaziah
Jehoram, struck with a disease of the intestines, dies in agony
story of Ahaziah (Ochozias), son of Jehoram, king of Judah (2 Kings 8:25-29; 2 Chronicles 22:1-9)
story of Athalia, queen of Judah (2 Kings 11:1-3, 11:13-16; 2 Chronicles 22:10-12, 23:12-15)
Athalia seizes the throne on the death of her son Ahaziah
Athaliah has all the members of the royal family killed
Joash is rescued by his aunt Jehosheba
death of Athalia: she is seized by soldiers, brought to the palace and killed at the Horse gate
story of Joash, son of Ahaziah, king of Judah (2 Kings 11:4 - 12:21; 2 Chronicles 23-24)
Joash is proclaimed king at the age of seven
Joash is brought up in the temple by Jehosheba and Jehoiada, the priest
Jehoiada gathers a group of soldiers, presents Joash to them and persuades them to swear allegiance to him
Joash, protected by the soldiers, is crowned and anointed king; the people acclaim him
Athalia hearing the noise of the people acclaiming King Joash, comes to the temple and sees the new king standing by a pillar; she tears her clothes in dismay
the people destroy the temple, altars and images of Baal, and slay Baal's priests
Joash's good achievements
the temple is repaired (~ Joash's good achievements)
a collection box is placed in the temple
the money from the collection box in the temple is used to pay the workmen
Joash reverses his policies, and the people revert to idolatry
death of Jehoiada
Zechariah, son of Jehoiada, warns the people
at the king's order the people stone Zechariah in the temple courtyard
King Hazael of Syria attacks Judah and Jerusalem
the treasures of the temple and the palace are sent as gifts to King Hazael, who then withdraws his army
Joash's death: two officials plot his death and slay him
Joash is killed while lying in bed
story of Amaziah, son of Joash, king of Judah (2 Kings 14:1-21; 2 Chronicles 25)
Amaziah becomes king and has the two officials who killed his father executed
Amaziah's victory over Edom
Amaziah reorganizes the army and hires troops in Israel
a prophet warns King Amaziah not to take the Israelite soldiers with him; they are sent away
the Edomite prisoners are led to the top of a cliff and thrown down
Amaziah worshipping the Edomite idols
a prophet condemns Amaziah
Amaziah is assassinated in Lachish; his body is carried back to Jerusalem on a horse
story of the kings and kingdom of Judah (part II)
story of Uzziah (Azariah), son of Amaziah, king of Judah (2 Kings 15:1-7; 2 Chronicles 26)
Uzziah's public achievements
Uzziah wages war against the Philistines
the fortifications of Jerusalem are strengthened ~ story of Uzziah
King Uzziah has a large army ready for battle
Uzziah's impiety
Uzziah grows arrogant and defies God by burning incense on the altar; Azariah, the priest, resists him and as the king gets angry, leprosy breaks out on his forehead
the priests force King Uzziah to leave the temple
story of Jotham, son of Uzziah, king of Judah (2 Kings 15:32-38; 2 Chronicles 27)
Jotham builds the North gate of the temple and strengthens the city wall
Jotham defeats the Ammonites
story of Ahaz, son of Jotham, king of Judah (2 Kings 16; 2 Chronicles 28)
Ahaz' apostasy
King Ahaz burns his own son as a sacrificial offering
Ahaz in Damascus sends to Uriah, the priest, a model of a Syrian altar; the altar is built and placed in the temple of Jerusalem
the temple is reorganized and some parts are closed up ~ Ahaz' apostasy
war with Syria and Israel ~ story of Ahaz
King Rezin of Syria and King Pekah of Israel defeat Ahaz and take many prisoners
Oded, a prophet, meets the returning Israelite army with the Judaean prisoners and exhorts the Israelites to let the prisoners go
four men are appointed to provide the Judaean prisoners with clothing and food, and all the prisoners are taken back to Judah ~ Ahaz' war with Syria and Israel
Ahaz asks Assyria for help ~ war with Syria and Israel
the Edomites raid Judah again
Ahaz takes silver and gold from the temple and the palace and sends it as a present to Tiglath-Pileser
the Assyrian king Tiglath-Pileser captures Damascus and kills Rezin
story of Hezekiah (Ezechias), son of Ahaz, king of Judah (2 Kings 18-20; 2 Chronicles 29-32)
Hezekiah's religious achievements
Hezekiah destroys the local shrines
Hezekiah crushes the idols
Hezekiah breaks Moses' brazen serpent
the purification of the temple ~ story of Hezekiah
the temple is repaired ~ story of Hezekiah
King Hezekiah assembles the Levites and priests and orders them to prepare the temple for worship
the temple is rededicated ~ story of Hezekiah
seven bulls, seven rams, seven lambs and seven goats are offered; the people sing and the priests play trumpets, harps and cymbals ~ story of Hezekiah
the Passover is celebrated again in Jerusalem ~ Hezekiah
preparations for Passover: messengers are sent throughout the country
people laugh at the messengers who are sent throughout the country by Hezekiah
a second celebration of the Passover is performed ~ Hezekiah
Hezekiah reforms religious life
the people bring gifts to the temple ~ story of Hezekiah
Hezekiah defeats the Philistines
war with the Assyrians ~ story of Hezekiah (2 Kings 18:9 - 19:37; Isaiah 36-37)
Hezekiah throws off the Assyrian yoke
Sennacherib, the Assyrian king, invades Judah and captures several cities
Hezekiah pays a large tribute to the king: the treasures from the palace and the temple
Sennacherib sends Rab-sakeh with an army to attack Jerusalem
Hezekiah, for the defense of Jerusalem, cuts off the supply of water outside the city
Jerusalem's walls are repaired and towers built on it
Hezekiah assembles an army and addresses the soldiers
the Assyrians arrive at Jerusalem and send for the king ~ story of Hezekiah
three emissaries leave the city of Jerusalem to meet the Assyrians; on the city walls the people sit listening to the discussions ~ Sennacherib's siege of Jerusalem
one of the Assyrian officials (Rab-sakeh) shouts to the people and urges them to surrender ~ Hezekiah at war with the Assyrians
the people of Jerusalem are silent and refuse to answer Rab-sakeh ~ Hezekiah at war with the Assyrians
Hezekiah on hearing the report of the three emissaries rends his clothes in grief ~ war with the Assyrians
King Hezekiah asks Isaiah's advice
King Hezekiah sends three men wearing sackcloth to Isaiah
Hezekiah receives a letter from Sennacherib with another threat
Hezekiah prays to God for delivery
Isaiah prophesying the retreat of the Assyrians
at night, an angel of the Lord decimates the Assyrian camp: 185.000 soldiers are killed
Sennacherib returns to Nineveh
when Sennacherib is worshipping in the temple, two of his sons kill him with their swords
Hezekiah's illness and recovery (2 Kings 20:1-11; Isaiah 38)
King Hezekiah falls ill and is visited by Isaiah, who tells him to get ready to die; Hezekiah turns his face to the wall, prays and then cries
as Isaiah is about to leave the palace God tells him to return to King Hezekiah and to announce his recovery
Isaiah prescribes figs to be placed on the king's boil
Hezekiah asks for a sign to prove that God will heal him
Isaiah prays to God and the shadow of the sundial goes back ten degrees
Hezekiah's song of praise
Hezekiah showing his treasure (2 Kings 20:12-19; Isaiah 39)
the king of Babylon, Merodach Baladan, sends Hezekiah a letter and a present
Hezekiah welcomes the messengers and shows them his wealth
Isaiah comes to King Hezekiah and prophesies that everything he owns will be carried off to Babylonia
story of Manasseh, son of Hezekiah, king of Judah (2 Kings 21:1-18; 2 Chronicles 33:1-20)
Manasseh's apostasy
Manasseh rebuilds the pagan places of worship and builds altars to Baal
Manasseh builds pagan altars in the temple of Jerusalem and worships the stars
Manasseh sacrifices his own son as a burnt offering
Manasseh practices magic and divination
misfortune brings Manasseh back to the true God
Sennacherib's son and successor, Asarhaddon of Syria, invades Judah and captures Manasseh
in captivity in Babylon, Manasseh becomes humble and begs God for help
the prayer of Manasseh
Manasseh returns to Jerusalem and rules again
the city wall of Jerusalem is strengthened ~ story of Manasseh
the idols and altars are removed from the temple of Jerusalem ~ story of Manasseh
story of Amon, son of Manasseh, king of Judah (2 Kings 21:19-26; 2 Chronicles 33:21-25)
Amon worships idols
Amon is killed in his palace
the people of Judah slay Amon's assassins
story of Josiah, son of Amon, king of Judah (2 Kings 22:1 - 23:30; 2 Chronicles 34-35)
the book of Law is discovered ~ story of Josiah
Josiah orders the repair of the temple
Saphan, the scribe, comes to the high priest Hilkiah, who tells him that he has found the book of Law in the temple
Saphan reads the book of Law aloud to the king who tears his clothes in dismay
King Josiah sends Hilkiah, Saphan and three other officials to Huldah, the prophetess, who predicts that the punishment of Jerusalem will come, but only after Josiah's death
Hilkiah, Saphan and three other officials report to King Josiah
Josiah does away with pagan worship
Josiah summons the elders, the priests and all the people to the temple
before the assembled people King Josiah reads the book of Law
standing by a pillar King Josiah makes a covenant with God to keep His laws
the people promise to keep the covenant ~ story of Josiah
all the idols are brought out of the temple, burned, and their ashes pounded to dust ~ story of Josiah
Josiah removes the horses and burns the chariots used in the worship of the sun-god
the pagan priests are either killed or suppressed ~ story of Josiah
all the pagan shrines over the entire kingdom are desecrated and destroyed ~ story of Josiah
the altar at Bethel is desecrated: bones taken out of some nearby tombs are burnt on the altar (the tomb of the prophet of Judah is spared) ~ story of Josiah
wizards and magicians are put away ~ story of Josiah
Josiah celebrates the Passover
Josiah assigns to the Levites and the priests the duties they are to perform
King Josiah and his officials contribute from their own herds for the sacrifices during the festival
the animals are killed and roasted over fire; other offerings are boiled in pots and cauldrons ~ Josiah celebrating the Passover
battle with the Egyptians and death of Josiah
King Necho II of Egypt traverses Palestine with his army
Josiah marches out to arrest Pharaoh's progress
Necho sends ambassadors to Josiah
in the battle of Megiddo, Josiah is struck by Egyptian arrows
Josiah's body is placed on a chariot and brought to Jerusalem
burial of Josiah
story of Jehohahaz (Joahaz), son of Josiah, king of Judah (2 Kings 23:31-34; 2 Chronicles 36:1-4)
Jehohahaz is taken prisoner by King Necho II and brought to Egypt
story of Jehoiakim (Joakim), son of Josiah, king of Judah (2 Kings 23:34 - 24:6; 2 Chronicles 36:5-8)
King Necho II makes Jehohahaz' brother, Eliakim, king of Judah and changes his name into Jehoiakim
Judah pays a large tribute to Pharaoh
Nebuchadnezzar (Nabuchodonosor) of Babylonia on his way to fight Egypt, invades Judah and Jehoiakim becomes a vassal of Babylon (2 Kings 24:1; 2 Chronicles 36:6-7; Daniel 1:1-2)
King Jehoiakim rebels against Babylon
the Babylonians are joined by bands of Syrians, Moabites and Ammonites
declining years and death of Jehoiakim
Jehoiakim is captured and taken to Babylonia in chains
story of the kings and kingdom of Judah (part III)
story of Jehoiachin (Joachin), son of Jehoiakim, king of Judah (2 Kings 24:8-16, 25:27-30; 2 Chronicles 36:9-10)
Jehoiachin becomes king
first siege of Jerusalem ~ story of Jehoiachin
Nebuchadnezzar captures the city; Jehoiachin, his mother, his wives, and the royal princes are carried away as prisoners (first siege of Jerusalem
all the treasures of the temple and the palace of Jerusalem are carried off to Babylon ~ first siege of Jerusalem
ten thousand Israelites, including the prophet Ezekiel, are deported to Babylon ~ story of Jehoiachin
when Evilmerodach becomes king of Babylon, Jehoiachin is released from prison and permitted to dine at the king's table for the rest of his life (2 Kings 25:27-30; Jeremiah 52:31-34)
story of Zedekiah, king of Judah (2 Kings 24:18 - 25:21; 2 Chronicles 36:11-21; Jeremiah 52:1-30)
Nebuchadnezzar makes Mattaniah, Jehoiachin's uncle, king and changes his name to Zedekiah
second siege of Jerusalem ~ story of Zedekiah
Nebuchadnezzar and his army set up camp outside the city of Jerusalem (second siege of Jerusalem)
famine afflicts the city of Jerusalem ~ story of Zedekiah
the city walls of Jerusalem are broken through; Zedekiah and the soldiers escape during the night
Zedekiah is captured by the Babylonians
Zedekiah is chained and brought before Nebuchadnezzar
Zedekiah's sons are put to death while he looks on
the leading men of Judah are executed ~ story of Zedekiah
King Zedekiah's eyes are put out
the fall of Jerusalem ~ story of Zedekiah
Nebuzaradan, commander of the Babylonian army, burns down the temple and the palace of Jerusalem ~ second siege of Jerusalem
the temple of Jerusalem is looted ~ story of Zedekiah
the city walls of Jerusalem are torn down ~ story of Zedekiah
the high priest and all the officials who were still in the city of Jerusalem are brought before Nebuchadnezzar, tortured and put to death
the people of Judah, except the poorest, are taken to Babylonia ~ story of Zedekiah
Gedaliah, governor of Judah (2 Kings 25:22-26)
Gedaliah is made governor of the land by Nebuchadnezzar at Mizpah
Gedaliah persuades Johanan and some of the officers and soldiers who had not surrendered, to settle in Judah and serve the king of Babylon
Ishmael and his men attack Mizpah and kill Gedaliah
Gedaliah is killed while eating with Ishmael and his men (Jeremiah 41:1-2)
eighty men who came to offer sacrifice in the temple are killed and their bodies thrown into a well (Jeremiah 41:4-7)
Johanan and the rest of the Judaeans flee to Egypt (Jeremiah 41:16-18)
the Babylonian Captivity of the Jews
story of Elijah (Elias)
Elijah at the brook Cherith (1 Kings 17:1-6)
Elijah announces to King Ahab that God will bring a long drought in the land to avenge the apostasy of Israel
Elijah fed by the raven(s): while the prophet is living by the brook, ravens bring him food
Elijah and the widow of Zarephath (1 Kings 17:7-24)
when the brook dries up, Elijah crosses over to the city of Zarephath; at the gate he meets a woman and her little son gathering wood (the woman's sticks may form a cross)
Elijah asks the widow of Zarephath to fetch him some food
Elijah fed by the widow of Zarephath
the miracle of the barrel of meal and the jar of oil: to reward the woman's charity Elijah has her store of meal and oil renewed as long as the famine prevails
Elijah restores the child of the widow of Zarephath to life
the son of the widow of Zarephath falls mortally ill
the widow of Zarephath complains to Elijah
Elijah takes the child of the widow of Zarephath and carries him upstairs
Elijah lays the child of the widow of Zarephath on his bed and three times stretches himself out on the boy
Elijah prays to God ~ story of the widow of Zarephath
Elijah hands the revived boy over to his mother, the widow of Zarephath
Elijah meets Ahab again (1 Kings 18:1-19)
preliminary events
the piety of Obadiah, governor of Ahab's house: when Queen Jezebel kills the Lord's priests, Obadiah hides a hundred of them in a cave and provides them with food
Ahab scours the country in search of Elijah and requires his men to swear that they could not find the prophet
God commands Elijah to present himself to King Ahab
at the height of the famine, Ahab orders Obadiah to search for grass for the horses and mules
on his way Obadiah meets Elijah who commands him to summon the king
Obadiah reports to Ahab, who then sets off to meet Elijah
Ahab is reproved by Elijah and asked to gather the priests of Baal on Mount Carmel for a contest
Elijah defies the priests of Baal; the end of the drought (1 Kings 18:20-46)
Ahab summons the priests of Baal and the people of Israel to meet on Mount Carmel
Elijah addressing the people
two sacrificial altars are set up ~ story of Elijah
an altar is prepared by the Baal-worshippers and a bull is laid upon it; all the priests' cries, wild dances and self-mutilations are in vain (sacrifice on Mount Carmel)
the Baal-worshippers are mocked by Elijah
Elijah takes twelve stones and repairs the ruined altar; he prepares his sacrifice
as Elijah prays, God sends fire which burns up not only his sacrifice but also the altar itself; the people fall prostrate
at Elijah's order, the priests of Baal are taken to the brook of Kishon and slain
the end of the drought ~ story of Elijah
Elijah climbs to the top of Mount Carmel where he bows down to the ground; a servant is sent to look towards the sea to check for rain
the servant reports he has seen a small cloud ~ story of Elijah
in a downpour of rain, Ahab returns to Jezreel in his chariot with Elijah running in front of him
Elijah and the angel; Elijah on Mount Horeb (1 Kings 19:1-18)
Jezebel sends a message to Elijah in which she threatens to take his life
Elijah flees into the wilderness (desert)
Elijah sits dejected under a juniper-tree and falls asleep
an angel wakes Elijah; a loaf of bread and a jar of water are usually at Elijah's head
an angel, holding a loaf of bread and a jar (or chalice) wakes Elijah
Elijah comes to Mount Horeb where he dwells in a cave
after a furious wind, an earthquake and a fire, Elijah hears God's voice and covers his face with his cloak
Elijah stands at the entrance of the cave on Mount Horeb and listens to God
the calling of Elisha (1 Kings 19:19-21)
Elijah finds Elisha ploughing with a team of oxen and puts his cloak on him
Elisha kills a pair of oxen, and boils their flesh with the wood of the yoke
Elisha's farewell meal with his father, mother and friends
Elisha pouring water over Elijah's hands (2 Kings 3:11)
Elijah and the messengers of King Ahaziah (2 Kings 1:3-16)
an angel orders Elijah to meet the messengers of King Ahaziah
Elijah sends the messengers back to King Ahaziah with the message that he is to die soon
after the messengers report to Ahaziah, the king dispatches an officer with fifty men to get Elijah
when they reach Elijah, fire comes down and kills the officer and his men; their replacement is stricken also
a third officer is sent by King Ahaziah; he falls on his knees and begs Elijah to spare his life and that of his men
an angel advises Elijah to go to the king with the officer
Elijah goes to Ahaziah and prophesies his death
the ascension of Elijah (2 Kings 2:1-18)
Elijah and Elisha conversing on their way to the Jordan
Elijah and Elisha pass by the cities of Bethel and Jericho and at both places they meet a group of young prophets
Elijah and Elisha stop by the bank of the Jordan; Elijah rolls up his cloak and strikes the water with it: the water divides
Elijah and Elisha cross to the other side of the Jordan
Elijah's farewell: Elisha asks that some of Elijah's spirit might be granted to him
a chariot, horses of fire and a whirlwind appear and Elijah is carried up into heaven; Elijah's cloak falls (or he hands it over to Elisha)
Elisha is acknowledged as Elijah's successor
Elisha picks up Elijah's cloak and goes back to the Jordan
Elisha strikes the water with Elijah's cloak, parts the water and recrosses the river; he thus wins recognition from the sons of the prophets
the young prophets urge Elisha to let them go and look for Elijah; but they search him in vain
Elisha is welcomed in Jericho
other scenes from the story of Elijah
birth of Elijah
two angels swaddle the infant Elijah in flames
Enoch receives Elijah into heaven
story of Elisha (Eliseus)
seven miracles of assistance ~ story of Elisha (Eliseus)
the water of Jericho is purified: when the citizens of Jericho complain about their water, Elisha puts some salt into a jar; he then throws the salt into the water (2 Kings 2:19-22)
the widow's oil: the little oil a woman has in store increases so that she and her son are able to fill many borrowed jars with it (2 Kings 4:1-7)
a widow, pressed for payment by a creditor, comes to Elisha who orders her to borrow as many empty jars as possible
Elisha and the Shunammite woman (2 Kings 4:8-37, 8:1-6)
the Shunammite woman's hospitality
Elisha dining with the Shunammite woman
the prophet Elisha is given room in the house of the Shunammite woman
Elisha promises the Shunammite woman a son in return for her hospitality
birth of the son of the Shunammite woman
when the son of the Shunammite woman joins his father and the harvest workers in the field he collapses
the son of the Shunammite woman dies in his mother's lap
the Shunammite woman rides out with her donkey to Elisha, bows down before him and taking hold of his feet, entreats him to come with her
Gehazi is sent to the house with Elisha's staff; he attempts unsuccessfully to revive the child of the Shunammite woman
raising of the Shunammite woman's son
Elisha finds the son of the Shunammite woman lying on his bed and prays to God
Elisha stretches himself out upon the child of the Shunammite woman
Gehazi fetches the Shunammite woman; when she sees her child alive she falls at Elisha's feet
the Shunammite woman and the famine
Elisha advises the Shunammite woman to leave the country

when the Shunammite woman returns later, she goes with her son to the king of Israel, whom she finds talking with Elisha's servant, and asks him for her house and land to be restored to her; the request is granted
the deadly pottage: Elisha purifies the poisoned pottage by throwing flour into it (2 Kings 4:38-41)
one of the sons of the prophets picks up herbs and wild gourds and throws them into a pot of boiling pottage; the pottage turns out to be inedible ~ story of Elisha
a hundred men are fed with twenty loaves of bread: Elisha receives barley bread of the first-fruits and a sack of corn which he multiplies to feed a hundred men
Naaman's leprosy (2 Kings 5)
Naaman, commander of the Syrian army, suffers from leprosy
a little maid servant, an Israelite captive, tells her mistress that a prophet of Samaria could cure her husband
Naaman is told about Elisha
Naaman goes to Samaria bringing a letter and many valuable presents from the Syrian king
when the letter of Naaman is shown to the king of Israel (Joram), he tears his clothes in dismay
Naaman comes to the door of Elisha's house; the prophet sends a servant to tell him to wash himself seven times in the Jordan
Naaman is reluctant to wash himself seven times in the Jordan but is persuaded by his servants
Naaman comes to the Jordan, dips himself seven times and is cured
Naaman urges Elisha to accept some gifts, but Elisha refuses them; Naaman asks two mule-loads of earth
Gehazi's punishment
Gehazi overtakes Naaman's chariot; he receives two talents and garments, which he conceals in Elisha's house
Elisha rebukes Gehazi and as punishment causes him to be smitten with Naaman's leprosy

the recovery of the axe-head: as one of the sons of the prophets is cutting a tree to build a new house for Elisha and his followers, his axe-head falls into the Jordan; Elisha makes the axe-head float by casting a stick into the water (2 Kings 6:1-7)
the cursing of the children: when Elisha is on his way some children mock him for his baldness; Elisha curses them (2 Kings 2:23-25)
two bears come out of the woods and tear the children who were mocking Elisha to pieces
the confounding of the Syrians ~ story of Elisha (2 Kings 6:8-23)
Elisha warns the Israelite king of the ambushes planned by the Syrian king, who consequently sends troops to capture the prophet
when Elisha's servant notices the Syrian troops he is terrified, but Elisha opens his eyes and he sees the hillside covered with horses and chariots of fire
the Syrians come before Elisha; he prays to God and the Syrians are struck with blindness
Elisha leads the blind Syrians into the city of Samaria
in Samaria Elisha restores the sight of the Syrians and causes the king of Israel to feed them, and to let them return peacefully to Syria
Elisha and Hazael (2 Kings 8:7-15)
Elisha goes to Damascus
being ill, Benhadad II, king of Syria, sends Hazael to consult Elisha
Hazael comes to Elisha with forty camels and many gifts
Elisha weeps and tells Hazael he will be king of Syria
Hazael kills Benhadad: he soaks a cloth in water and smothers the king with it
Hazael becomes king of Syria
Elisha has Jehu anointed king of Israel (2 Kings 9:1-13)
Elisha sends one of the sons of the prophets to Ramoth with a jar of oil to anoint Jehu
the young prophet finds Jehu sitting with his fellow-officers
the young prophet goes inside with Jehu; there he pours the oil on Jehu's head and orders him to slay Ahab and all his family
when Jehu tells the officers about the young prophet's mission, they spread their cloaks on the stairs, blow trumpets and hail him
Elisha's sickness and death (2 Kings 13:14-20)
Joash, king of Israel, comes to visit the sick prophet Elisha
Elisha tells Joash to shoot an arrow through the window towards Syria and predicts that Joash will be victorious
Elisha tells Joash to strike the ground with arrows and predicts that he will have only three victories over the Syrians
Elisha dies
burial of Elisha
Elisha's bones (2 Kings 13:21)
during a funeral a band of ransacking Moabites is seen approaching and the corpse is thrown hastily into Elisha's tomb; when it touches Elisha's bones the man comes back to life
prophets (before and during the Babylonian Captivity)
the book of Amos
Amos, the herdsman of Tekoa, prophesies at Bethel (Amos 1-2)
the Lord will roar from Zion ~ prophecy of Amos
the Lord will send a fire into the house of Hazael
the Lord will break the bar of Damascus ~ prophecy of Amos
the Lord will send a fire upon Judah and it shall devour the palace of Jerusalem ~ prophecy of Amos
other prophecies of destruction ~ the book of Amos
Amos addresses the women ('cows') of Bashan (Amos 4:1-3)
Amos' visions (Amos 7 - 9:8)
the vision of the grasshoppers ~ book of Amos
the vision of the devouring fire ~ the book of Amos
the vision of the Lord standing on a wall, with a plumbline in his hand ~ book of Amos
Amos sees a basket of fruit ~ visions of Amos
Amos sees the Lord standing on the altar, ordering its destruction
Amos is killed by Amaziah, a priest at Bethel
other scenes from Amos
other scenes from Amos (with BOOK CHAPTER:VERSE)
the book of Hosea
the Lord speaks to Hosea 'Go, take yourself a wife of harlotry ...' (Hosea 1:2)
Hosea, Gomer and the three children (Hosea 1:3-11)
the marriage of Hosea and the whore Gomer
the first son of Hosea and Gomer is born; the Lord tells Hosea to name him Jezreel
Hosea and the adulteress (Hosea 3)
Hosea's prophecies; Israel reproved and threatened for its impiety and idolatry (Hosea 4-14)
the book of Isaiah
Isaiah communicating with God
prayer of Isaiah and apparition of God (Isaiah 26:9, 45:6)
Isaiah's visions
in the temple filled with smoke, the Lord sits on a throne; above it angels, each one with six wings ~ Isaiah's visions (Isaiah 6:1-4)
purification of Isaiah: an angel touches Isaiah's lips with a burning coal, taken from the altar with tongs ~ Isaiah's visions (Isaiah 6:5-13)
other visions of Isaiah
Isaiah's prophecies
Isaiah's prophecy of the birth of Christ ('Immanuel') (possibly with Mary, the angel Gabriel and King Ahaz) (Isaiah 7:14-16)
Isaiah's prophecy of the Passion of Christ (Isaiah 52:13 - 53:12)
'All we like sheep have gone astray' ~ Isaiah's prophecies (Isaiah 53:6)
Isaiah's prophecy of the tree of Jesse (Isaiah 11:1)
Isaiah's prophecy of the peaceable kingdom: 'the wolf shall dwell with the lamb' (Isaiah 11:6-9)
Isaiah's prophecy of the burden of Babel, Moab, Damascus, etc.
Isaiah's prophecy of the fall of Babel (Isaiah 14:12-20)
other prophecies of Isaiah

the opening of the seven seals ~ Revelation of John
the four horsemen of the Apocalypse
opening of the first seal: the man on the white horse with crown, bow and arrow (Victory)
opening of the second seal: the man on the red horse with a sword (War)
opening of the third seal: the man on the black horse with a pair of scales (Famine)
opening of the fourth seal: the man on the pale horse with a scythe (Death)
opening of the fifth seal: white robes are given to (the souls of) the martyrs under the altar
opening of the sixth seal: a great earthquake, the sun turns black, the moon red as blood, and the stars fall on earth; mankind hiding in caves
opening of the seventh seal: silence in heaven
the angel with the golden censer: smoke of the incense ascends with the prayers of the saints ~ opening of the seventh seal
the seven angels with trumpets ~ Revelation of John
the first of the seven angels sounds the trumpet: hail, fire and blood is cast upon the earth
the second of the seven angels sounds the trumpet: a great burning mountain is cast into the sea
the third of the seven angels sounds the trumpet: a great burning star (Wormwood) poisons the rivers and fountains
the fourth of the seven angels sounds the trumpet: the sun, the moon and the stars are partially darkened
an angel (or eagle) crying the three woes ~ the seven angels with trumpets
the fifth of the seven angels sounds the trumpet: the falling star opens up the bottomless pit: smoke comes out
the plague of the monstrous locusts with crowns, led by Apollyon
the sixth of the seven angels sounds the trumpet: the four angels of destruction are released
the army of horsemen ~ the seven angels with trumpets

the temple of God in heaven ~ the seven angels with trumpets
the four winds are restrained by four angels
sealing of the tribes of Israel, the 144-thousand

John measuring the temple

Medea's vengeance on Pelias
Medea boils an old ram in a cauldron: a young lamb comes out; the daughters of Pelias watch the scene

the Argonauts see the torches on the roof of Pelias' palace and rush into Iolcus

prelude to the war against Thebes
Polynices, banished from Thebes by his brother Eteocles, comes to Argos

Polynices and Tydeus marry Argia and Deipyle, the daughters of Adrastus
the departure (of the Seven) for Thebes

Amphiaraus being reluctant, Polynices bribes Eriphyle, Amphiaraus' wife, with the necklace formerly belonging to Harmonia; Eriphyle discloses Amphiaraus' hiding-place and he is thus compelled to join the enterprise
the march on Thebes
the army at Nemea
being short of water, the army is guided to a spring by Hypsipyle, the nurse of Lycurgus' son Opheltes
the young Opheltes, left on the ground, is bitten by a snake (or dragon) and dies
on their return the Seven find the child Opheltes dead; they kill the snake (or dragon), bury Opheltes, and institute the Nemean games in the boy's honour
Tydeus is sent as herald and defeats the Theban leaders one by one in single combat
the army before Thebes

Ulysses awakes on the shore where the Phaeacians left him; Minerva disguises him as an old beggar (Homer, Odyssey XIII)
Ulysses meets Eumaeus, the old swine-herd, and goes to the latter's hut (Homer, Odyssey XIV)

the end of the suitors

(1) Hercules chokes the Nemean lion with his arms

(4) the Erymanthian boar is captured by Hercules
Hercules carries the boar across his shoulders to Eurystheus, who takes refuge in a bronze tub

(6) the Stymphalian birds are shot by Hercules, or driven away with a bronze rattle

the story of Aeneas' wanderings to Italy (Virgil, Aeneid)
Aeneas' wanderings to Italy: from Troy to Carthage (Virgil, Aeneid II-III)
Aeneas leaves the country of Troy
Venus appears to Aeneas, who is just about to kill Helen, and advises him to flee
a miracle occurs in Aeneas' house: Ascanius' head catches fire but it does not harm him
'Pius Aeneas': Aeneas, leading Ascanius, escapes from burning Troy, carrying his father Anchises with the Penates; his wife Creusa, who sets out with them, is lost on the way
Aeneas searching for Creusa; her spirit appears to him
Aeneas builds a fleet
the fleet of Aeneas sets out
stay of Aeneas on Thrace: miracle of the bleeding bush on Polydorus' grave; the spirit of Polydorus advises Aeneas to flee
stay of Aeneas on Delos: meeting with Anius, and consultation of the Delian oracle; the Trojans offer sacrifices to the gods
stay of Aeneas on Crete: a pestilence ravages the Trojans
the Penates appear to Aeneas in a dream
stay of Aeneas on the Strophades Islands: fight with the Harpies that befoul the crew's food
the Harpy Celaeno foretells the future to Aeneas and his crew
sacrifices are made to Jupiter and games are held on the shore of Actium by Aeneas and his crew
stay of Aeneas on Epirus, where the Trojans find Helenus established as king and married to Andromache
first stay of Aeneas in Sicily
on arrival in Sicily, Anchises, standing on the quarter-deck, offers unwatered wine and invokes the gods
the Trojans pass Charybdis ~ Aeneid
the Trojans meet Achaemenides, left behind by Ulysses in Polyphemus' cave, and take him with them
the Trojans escape from Polyphemus and the Cyclopes
death of Anchises
Aeneas reaches Africa (Virgil, Aeneid I)
Aeneas' fleet cast on the coast of Libya
Aeneas and Achates go hunting for provisions
the meeting of Aeneas and Achates with Venus, disguised as a huntress; she points out twelve swans in the sky
Venus covers Aeneas and Achates with a cloud
Aeneas and Achates reach Carthage, where building is in progress
in the temple of Juno Aeneas and Achates look at scenes from the Trojan war depicted on the wall
Dido appears in the temple of Juno; a Trojan deputation asks her permission to beach and repair the ships
the meeting of Aeneas and Dido; when he approaches her throne, the cloud enveloping him and Achates vanishes
Dido leads Aeneas and his companions to her palace
the banquet of Aeneas and Dido
Venus gives Cupid the form and features of Ascanius
Achates and Ascanius-Cupid on their way to Carthage with presents
the presents are offered to Dido, she fondles Ascanius-Cupid
Aeneas tells Dido of his wanderings
the tragedy of Dido (Virgil, Aeneid IV)
Dido tormented by her love for Aeneas
Juno and Venus agree that Aeneas shall marry Dido
Dido and Aeneas hunting
Dido and Aeneas departing for the hunt
Dido and Aeneas shelter from the storm in a cave
Fama spreads the rumour of Dido's love-affair
Iarbas complains to Jupiter, who sends Mercury to Aeneas
Mercury summons Aeneas, engaged in building activities, to leave Carthage
the Trojans' departure from Carthage
Aeneas has his fleet put into readiness; complaints of Dido
Dido arguing with Anna, her sister
Anna before Aeneas, entreating him not to leave
after Mercury has appeared again to the sleeping Aeneas, the Trojan fleet sails
death of Dido; she climbs the funeral pyre and falls upon the sword of Aeneas
Iris cuts a lock from Dido's hair to release her soul
second stay of Aeneas in Sicily (Virgil, Aeneid V)
Aeneas and his companions meet with Acestes, their kinsman
celebration of the anniversary of the death of Anchises
Aeneas sacrificing at Anchises' grave: a snake appears
the contests held in memory of Anchises
the boxing contest: Dares and Entellus
the shooting contest during Aeneas' stay in Sicily: a fluttering dove, attached to the mast of a ship, is used as target
the riding display by thirty-six youths led by Ascanius
Iris, in the guise of Beroe, an old woman, incites the Trojan women to rebellion; they set the ships on fire
a rain-storm extinguishes the fire lighted by the Trojan women
Aeneas' departure from Sicily
Anchises' spirit appears to Aeneas in his sleep
Aeneas leaves some of the Trojans under the protection of Acestes
Aeneas' fleet sails away; Hypnos puts Palinurus to sleep, who then falls overboard and is lost
Aeneas' fleet passes the Sirens
the arrival at Cumae and the visit to the underworld (Virgil, Aeneid VI)
the arrival of Aeneas at Cumae, where they consult Deiphobe, the Cumaean Sibyl, who foretells of Aeneas' wars in Latium
returning to the beach the Trojans find Misenus, the trumpet blower, dead
Misenus challenges Triton to a musical competition; he is dragged into the sea and is drowned by the god
the funeral of Misenus
Aeneas plucks the 'Golden Bough' by the aid of two doves
Aeneas' visit to the underworld
Aeneas, guided by the Sibyl, enters the underworld through the cave of Avernus
Aeneas and the Sibyl reach the Styx, where they meet the ghosts of the unburied dead, among others Palinurus
Charon conveys Aeneas and the Sibyl in his boat; they alight at the gates of Pluto's kingdom
Cerberus is offered a drugged cake ~ Aeneas' visit to the underworld
Aeneas and the Sibyl meet various groups of the dead, among them is Dido, who turns aside
Aeneas and the Sibyl pass by Tartarus
Aeneas affixes the 'Golden Bough' to the threshold of Pluto's palace
Aeneas in the Elysian Fields
Musaeus offers Aeneas to show the way to Anchises
Aeneas finds Anchises in the underworld, and vainly seeks to embrace him
Aeneas sees ghosts drinking at the river Lethe
Anchises foretells the history of Rome to Aeneas
Aeneas and the Sibyl leave the underworld through the ivory gate
the Trojans reach the mouth of the Tiber and land in Latium (Virgil, Aeneid VII-VIII)
the Trojans eat cakes of bread which they have used as platters; thus fulfilling the Harpy's prophecy; they hail their new fatherland
the Trojans with King Latinus
signs from heaven warn Latinus: a dense cloud of bees hangs upon the sacred laurel-tree
Lavinia's long hair catches fire during a sacrifice
Latinus consults the oracle of Faunus
the Trojan embassy sent by Aeneas is welcomed by Latinus, who offers to make an alliance and to give Lavinia in marriage
Juno goes to Alecto, the Fury, to arouse sedition
Alecto flings a snake from her hair into the bosom of Latinus' wife Amata
Alecto, in the guise of an old woman, approaches Turnus in his sleep and sets him against Aeneas
when Ascanius is hunting, Alecto drives his hounds onto the trail of a sacred stag
the wounding of the sacred stag by Ascanius causes an affray
the Italian tribes gather to expel the Trojans ~ Aeneid
Juno opens the gates of war
Aeneas secures help for the Trojans
Aeneas' departure from Latium to secure help
the river-god Tiberinus appears to Aeneas in his sleep
Aeneas finds a white sow with thirty young, and sacrifices them to Juno
Aeneas with Evander
arrival of Aeneas at Pallanteum: while holding out an olive-branch he meets Pallas on the shore
Pallas brings Aeneas to his father Evander, who is sacrificing to Hercules in a grove outside the Arcadian city
Venus asks Vulcan to forge Aeneas' armour
Venus hands over the armour to Aeneas
the armour of Aeneas
the battle of Latium (I): the siege of the Trojan camp and the return of Aeneas
the siege of the Trojan camp ~ battle of Latium (Virgil, Aeneid IX)
Turnus blockades the Trojan camp
Juno sends Iris to Turnus to incite him to war
when Turnus sets the Trojan ships on fire they turn into sea-nymphs at Cybele's request
Nisus and Euryalus pass through the enemy lines at night
Nisus and Euryalus slay some of the enemies in their drunken sleep
Nisus and Euryalus fall in with a group of enemy soldiers and are killed
the heads of Nisus and Euryalus are displayed on spear-points
Euryalus' mother mourning her son
Ascanius' first deeds: he kills Numanus (Remulus), Turnus' brother-in-law
Apollo, in the guise of Butes, advises Ascanius to abstain from further fighting
Turnus sweeps the battle-field and kills among others Bitias and Pandarus
Turnus is cut off by the Trojans, but escapes by plunging into the river
the return of Aeneas and the Relief ~ battle of Latinum (Virgil, Aeneid X)
assembly of the gods ~ Aeneas' return to the battle of Latium
Aeneas secures the alliance of Tarchon and his Etruscans
sailing home Aeneas encounters the nymphs, into which the burning ships were changed; they inform him about the besieged Trojan camp
Turnus opposes Aeneas and his troops on the beach
Pallas' heroic deeds
Pallas is killed by Turnus
Turnus with the spoils of Pallas
the body of Pallas is carried away on a shield
Turnus pursues a phantom of Aeneas, contrived by Juno, and is borne away
Aeneas wounds Mezentius, whom Lausus, his son, tries to save
Lausus is killed by Aeneas
the body of Lausus is brought to Mezentius, who is staunching his wounds near the river
Mezentius confronts Aeneas again, and is killed together with his horse
battle of Latium (II): respite and battle again (Virgil, Aeneid XI); the last deeds of Turnus (Virgil, Aeneid XII)
respite of the battle of Latium
the spoils of Mezentius are offered to Mars
the body of Pallas is sent to Evander
sorrow of Evander and funeral of Pallas
a truce is arranged between the Trojans and the Latins to pay the last honours to the dead
gathering of the Latin leaders which is interrupted by the report that the Trojans are moving against the city
battle in Latium after the breaking of the truce
a cavalry engagement (~ battle of Latium) in which Camilla takes the lead
Tarchon plucks Venulus from his horse
Arruns kills Camilla
last instructions of the dying Camilla to her friend Acca
the nymph Opis kills Arruns with one of Diana's arrows
last deeds of Turnus
Turnus before Latinus: he wants to meet Aeneas in single combat; Amata tries in vain to stop him
a compact is made with the Trojans; Aeneas ratifies the agreement with Latinus in full view of both armies
Juturna, Turnus' sister, incites the Rutulians to battle
Tolumnius hurls a spear against the Trojans; the treaty is void
the fighting is resumed
Aeneas is wounded; Venus secretly puts a healing plant in the water with which Japyx is bathing the wound
Aeneas back to the war; Juturna, in the guise of the charioteer Metiscus, darts away with Turnus to evade Aeneas
the Trojans attack Laurentium; Amata hangs herself
single combat of Turnus and Aeneas
Jupiter weighs in a pair of scales the destinies of Turnus and Aeneas
Jupiter sends one of the Furies in the form of a dark bird which flies into Turnus' face and beats against his shield
Juturna withdraws from the battle and dives into a stream
Turnus is killed by Aeneas

the ghost of Dido warns Anna in a dream for the jealousy of Lavinia

Camilla is brought up by her father in the woods and is fed upon milk of mares
Camilla is dedicated to the service of Diana and inured to hunting

Dido leaves Phoenicia with her treasures

a bull's hide is cut into thin strips to cover as much land as possible

suffering, misfortune of Rhea Silvia
Amulius makes Rhea Silvia (Ilia) a Vestal, thus condemning her to perpetual virginity
Rhea Silvia, after having given birth to Romulus and Remus, is flung into prison by her uncle Amulius
death of Rhea Silvia: she is drowned by Amulius

reconciliation of the Sabines and the Romans: the women, some holding their babies, others with their hair loose, and possibly encouraged by Hersilia call for peace in the midst of the two fighting armies

while Tarpeia is fetching water outside the city-gate she is bribed by Titus Tatius into opening the gates of the city
suffering, misfortune of Tarpeia
death of Tarpeia: she is crushed under the shields of the Sabines, as punishment for betraying her country
